context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Meghan Markle pledges to 'shine a light' on women's rights
context_meta.summary: Meghan Markle has indicated that she is not ready to abandon her campaigning as she prepares to join the royal family, highlighting her support for women's rights. Markle, an ardent feminist, has advocated for women and ethnic minorities in the past, but after deleting her social media accounts, it appeared that she might be less inclined to speak out. “I think right now in the climate we are seeing so many campaigns, I mean #MeToo and Time's Up, and there is no better time to really continue to shine a light on women feeling empowered, and people really helping to support them – men included,” Markle said. The Los Angeles-born actor has worked as an ambassador for UN Women and the charity World Vision.

context_meta.title: Problematic Women: Can You be a Conservative and a Feminist?
context_meta.summary: In the wake of one of the country's most deadly school shootings, Americans are engaged in a heated debate over the Second Amendment. A gunman left 17 people dead Feb. 14 at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. Students are speaking out about their emotional trauma, and NRA spokeswoman Dana Loesch went face-to-face with Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel in a CNN “town hall debate” on guns. We address that and more, including Hollywood star Jennifer Lawrence's outfit outrage, the shallow feminism of Sports Illustrated, and presidential infidelity, in this week's special CPAC edition of Problematic Women. context_meta.title: Northern Ireland abortion laws violate women's rights, U.N. body says
context_meta.summary: By Tom Miles GENEVA (Reuters) - The United Kingdom violates women's rights in Northern Ireland by unduly restricting their access to abortion, a report by the U.N. Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) said on Friday. “Denial of abortion and criminalisation of abortion amounts to discrimination against women because it is a denial of a service that only women need. “The situation in Northern Ireland constitutes violence against women that may amount to torture or cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment,” she said.

context_meta.title: Jennifer Lawrence says she's taking a break from acting, and it's for an incredible reason
context_meta.summary: Though she's one of the most in-demand movie stars on the planet, consistently topping the lists of highest-paid actresses year after year, it seems Jennifer Lawrence has bigger plans in mind for 2018. Lawrence just revealed she's stepping away from the spotlight to focus on political activism. And we say, you go, girl. In the past few years, the 27-year-old has become an advocate for gender equality, penning a stunning essay on Hollywood's wage gap back in 2015. And it seems Lawrence is hoping to do more than just use her own voice, as she's planning to work with young people on getting their voices heard. context_meta.title: Stevens Institute plans annual reading of the Vagina Monologues
context_meta.summary: In the fight to put an end to violence against women and girls, the DeBaun Performing Arts Center will be presenting its 18th annual reading of The Vagina Monologues, by Eve Ensler, on Feb. 22. at 9 p.m. at the DeBaun Auditorium at 24 5th St, Hoboken. Admission is $5 at the door.  With its recurring theme of female empowerment and individuality, The Vagina Monologues is known for its personal monologues which are read by a diverse group of women. Each monologue touches on matters such as sex, work, body image, love, rape, and birth.  The Elysian Cafe, at 1001 Washington Street, Hoboken, will be offering tickets to the show for $15 each on the night of the performance. context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Women’s suffrage: After 100 years since millions of women got the vote around the world, how do their rights compare now?
context_meta.summary: Amid a groundswell in sexual harassment claims across Hollywood, Westminster, the City of London and elsewhere, it is with bitter-sweet sentiment that we celebrate this year’s centenary of the Representation of the People Act on 6 February. The legislation granted some women in the UK the right to vote, but while its anniversary serves as a reminder of how far we’ve come, it should also underscore how much work still lies ahead. April’s gender pay gap reporting deadline is perhaps the next important test.

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: The 1910s: 'We have sanitised our history of the suffragettes'
context_meta.summary: EM Forster published Howards End; Cora Crippen was murdered by her husband, sparking an international manhunt as he went on the run with his mistress; and the suffragettes felt the wrath of the home secretary, Winston Churchill, on “Black Friday”, as 300 women attempted to enter parliament to argue for their rights. After the ensuing riot, the government desperately attempted to cover up evidence of police brutality and serious physical assaults on the suffragettes, but the damage was done. For many of the women present, the government's use of extreme force on what had been a peaceful protest was the final straw. Led by the Pankhurst family, the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU) – the suffragettes – conducted a nationwide bombing and arson campaign unlike anything this country had ever experienced, or has seen since.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: French leader says Tunisia's success impacts France, others
context_meta.summary: next prev TUNIS, Tunisia –  French President Emmanuel Macron held out Tunisia's budding democracy as a model at a turning point with huge challenges ahead, and whose success will impact nations on both sides of the Mediterranean. He said Thursday in an address to Tunisian lawmakers that economic and social reforms "are indispensable" for the nation that inspired the Arab Spring seven years ago by chasing out its autocratic leader. Tunisia faces social unrest and is fighting Islamic extremists, some crossing from neighboring Libya, once a major economic partner. Macron took a swipe at France, the United States and other nations in the coalition that toppled Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi in 2011,

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: Jenni Murray on the 1960s: 'I hid my twinset and strode out as the mod I longed to be'
context_meta.summary: I was 10 in 1960 and lived my teenage years through the decade that saw the sexual revolution and of which people say: “If you remember the 60s, you weren't there.” Clearly, the sex and drugs didn't feature for me, so I remember it all with complete accuracy – though I experienced it only through the radio, records and TV. My mother was the kind of woman who declared, firmly: “No daughter of mine is going to a concert and screaming at those scruffy Liverpool Beatles.” I never forgave her. The women who had the greatest influence on me and my fellow teens were Cathy McGowan, who presented Ready Steady Go!; Dusty Springfield, whose eye makeup was stunning and, she confirmed to me in an interview

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Joan Bakewell on feminism in the 1970s: 'Might a woman read the news?' I asked. 'Absolutely not'
context_meta.summary: By the 70s, I was a mother of two children and co-presenter with three men of BBC Two's chatshow Late Night Line-Up. The arrival of the Equal Pay Act seemed hardly to make a ripple in the BBC: it kept to its own hierarchies. I was earning less than my co-presenters. When they found out, they lobbied our editor to have my pay increased. It was the sort of gesture sympathetic men made in those days. I tried out feminism on the BBC. “Might a woman one day read the news?” I asked of the head of news. “Absolutely not,” I was told. Institutions were proving harder to change than individuals.
